stem: During an emergency appendectomy, the client's end-tidal CO2 rises sharply, and his jaw becomes rigid. His temperature begins to rise rapidly (103Â°F and climbing). Complete the bowtie to guide management.

actions.text: Apply external heat to maintain core temperature
Terminate inhalation anesthetics and hyperventilate with 100% O2

rationale.correct: MH is a genetic reaction to succinylcholine or gas anesthetics. High ETCO2 and muscle rigidity are early signs; high fever is a LATE sign. Priority is the antidote (Dantrolene) and stopping the trigger. Temp and ETCO2 are critical monitoring points.
rationale.incorrect: Atropine won't help MH muscle hypermetabolism. Heat will kill the client. MH is a hypermetabolic state needing cooling, not heating.
clinicalPearls: MH is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder; always ask about family history of anesthesia problems.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Fever is the first sign
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Muscle rigidity (jaw) and high CO2 are the earliest indicators.

mnemonic.title: MH
mnemonic.expansion:
M = Malignant
H = Hyperthermia

Key Actions: Administer IV Dantrolene Sodium STAT; Terminate inhalation anesthetics and hyperventilate with 100% O2
Key Monitoring: Body temperature and Heart rate; End-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) levels

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Malignant Hyperthermia
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Administer IV Dantrolene Sodium STAT; Terminate inhalation anesthetics and hyperventilate with 100% O2. Monitor: Body temperature and Heart rate; End-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) levels. Atropine won't help MH muscle hypermetabolism. Heat will kill the client. MH is a hypermetabolic state needing cooling, not heating.
